1.content:
High above the city, on a tall column, stood the statue of the Happy
Prince. He was gilded all over with thin leaves of fine gold, for eyes
he had two bright sapphires, and a large red ruby glowed on his
sword-hilt.
He was very much admired indeed. "He is as beautiful as a weathercock,"
remarked one of the Town Councillors who wished to gain a reputation for
having artistic tastes; "only not quite so useful," he added, fearing
lest people should think him unpractical, which he really was not.
"Why can't you be like the Happy Prince?" asked a sensible mother of her
little boy who was crying for the moon. "The Happy Prince never dreams
of crying for anything."
"I am glad there is some one in the world who is quite happy," muttered
a disappointed man as he gazed at the wonderful statue.
"He looks just like an angel," said the Charity Children as they came
out of the cathedral in their bright scarlet cloaks and their clean
white pinafores.
"How do you know?" said the Mathematical Master, "you have never seen
one."

1.grade5: High above the city, on a tall column, stood a beautiful statue of a prince. He was covered in thin leaves of gold and had two bright blue stones for eyes. A big red stone glowed on his sword handle. Everyone thought he was very pretty. 'He is as beautiful as a weather vane,' said one of the town leaders who wanted to sound smart. 'But not quite as useful,' he added, because he didn't want people to think he wasn't practical. 'Why can't you be like the Happy Prince?' asked a kind mother to her little boy who was crying. 'The Happy Prince never cries for anything.' A sad man looked at the statue and said, 'I wish I could be happy like him.' The children from the charity came out of the church wearing bright red clothes and white aprons. They thought the prince looked like an angel. 'How do you know?' asked a teacher. 'You've never seen one before.'

2.content:
"Ah! but we have, in our dreams," answered the children; and the
Mathematical Master frowned and looked very severe, for he did not
approve of children dreaming.
One night there flew over the city a little Swallow. His friends had
gone away to Egypt six weeks before, but he had stayed behind, for he
was in love with the most beautiful Reed. He had met her early in the
spring as he was flying down the river after a big yellow moth, and had
been so attracted by her slender waist that he had stopped to talk to
her.
"Shall I love you?" said the Swallow, who liked to come to the point at
once, and the Reed made him a low bow. So he flew round and round her,
touching the water with his wings, and making silver ripples. This was
his courtship, and it lasted all through the summer.
"It is a ridiculous attachment," twittered the other Swallows; "she has
no money, and far too many relations;" and indeed the river was quite
full of Reeds. Then, when the autumn came they all flew away.

2.grade5: One night, a little swallow flew over the city. His friends had left for Egypt six weeks earlier, but he stayed behind because he was in love with a beautiful reed. He met her early in the spring when he was flying down the river after catching a big yellow moth. The reed's slender waist caught his eye, and he stopped to talk to her.

3.content:
After they had gone he felt lonely, and began to tire of his lady-love.
"She has no conversation," he said, "and I am afraid that she is a
coquette, for she is always flirting with the wind." And certainly,
whenever the wind blew, the Reed made the most graceful curtseys.
"I admit that she is domestic," he continued, "but I love travelling,
and my wife, consequently, should love travelling also."
"Will you come away with me?" he said finally to her; but the Reed shook
her head, she was so attached to her home.
"You have been trifling with me," he cried. "I am off to the Pyramids.
Good-bye!" and he flew away.
All day long he flew, and at night-time he arrived at the city. "Where
shall I put up?" he said; "I hope the town has made preparations."
Then he saw the statue on the tall column.
"I will put up there," he cried; "it is a fine position, with plenty of
fresh air." So he alighted just between the feet of the Happy Prince.

3.grade5: After he left, he felt very lonely and started to get bored with his girlfriend. 'She doesn't talk much,' he said, 'and I think she might be playing hard to get.' Whenever the wind blew, the reed would curtsy in a very elegant way. He admitted that she was good at taking care of things at home, but he loved traveling and thought his wife should love it too. 'Will you come with me?' he asked her, but she said no because she liked staying at home. 'You were just teasing me,' he said. 'I'm going to the Pyramids now. Goodbye!' and he flew away. He kept flying all day until nightfall when he arrived in a big city. 'Where should I stay?' he asked. 'Is the town ready for visitors?' Then he saw a tall statue on a column. 'I'll stay right here,' he said, 'it's a great spot with fresh air.' So he landed between the Happy Prince's feet.

4.content:
"I have a golden bedroom," he said softly to himself as he looked round,
and he prepared to go to sleep; but just as he was putting his head
under his wing a large drop of water fell on him. "What a curious
thing!" he cried; "there is not a single cloud in the sky, the stars are
quite clear and bright, and yet it is raining. The climate in the north
of Europe is really dreadful. The Reed used to like the rain, but that
was merely her selfishness."
Then another drop fell.
"What is the use of a statue if it cannot keep the rain off?" he said;
"I must look for a good chimney-pot," and he determined to fly away.
But before he had opened his wings, a third drop fell, and he looked up,
and saw-- Ah! what did he see?
The eyes of the Happy Prince were filled with tears, and tears were
running down his golden cheeks. His face was so beautiful in the
moonlight that the little Swallow was filled with pity.
"Who are you?" he said.
"I am the Happy Prince."
"Why are you weeping then?" asked the Swallow; "you have quite
drenched me."

4.grade5: There was a boy who had a special room in his house that was all golden. He was getting ready for bed, but just as he lay down, a big drop of water fell on him. 'Wow, this is weird!' he said. 'I don't see any clouds in the sky, and yet it's raining. The weather in some parts of Europe can be really bad.' He used to like rainy days because they made his friend, the Reed, happy. But now he was worried. Another drop fell, and he thought, 'If I'm going to stay here, I need a special roof to keep me dry.' So he decided to fly away. But before he could open his wings, another drop fell, and he looked up. That's when he saw something amazing.

5.content:
"When I was alive and had a human heart," answered the statue, "I did
not know what tears were, for I lived in the Palace of Sans-Souci, where
sorrow is not allowed to enter. In the daytime I played with my
companions in the garden, and in the evening I led the dance in the
Great Hall. Round the garden ran a very lofty wall, but I never cared
to ask what lay beyond it, everything about me was so beautiful.
My courtiers called me the Happy Prince, and happy indeed I was, if
pleasure be happiness. So I lived, and so I died. And now that I am dead
they have set me up here so high that I can see all the ugliness and all
the misery of my city, and though my heart is made of lead yet I cannot
choose but weep."
"What! is he not solid gold?" said the Swallow to himself. He was too
polite to make any personal remarks out loud.

little street there is a poor house. One of the windows is open, and
through it I can see a woman seated at a table. Her face is thin and
worn, and she has coarse, red hands, all pricked by the needle, for she

to give him but river water, so he is crying. Swallow, Swallow, little
Swallow, will you not bring her the ruby out of my sword-hilt? My feet
are fastened to this pedestal and I cannot move."

26.content_hindi: प्रतिमा ने कोमल, मधुर स्वर में कहा, "दूर, एक छोटी सी गली में, एक गरीब घर है। एक खिड़की खुली है और वहाँ से मैं एक महिला को मेज पर बैठी हुई देख सकती हूँ। उसका चेहरा पतला और ऊब गया है, और उसके हाथ खुरचीले और लाल हैं, जिसमें कई सुइयां लगी हुई हैं। वह सिलाई करती है। वह अगली शाही गेंद पर पहनने के लिए महारानी की प्रतीक्षा कर रही सबसे खूबसूरत महिलाओं के लिए एक साटन गाउन पर पैशन-फ्लावर की कढ़ाई करने में व्यस्त है। कमरे के कोने में एक बिस्तर पर उसका छोटा लड़का बीमार पड़ा है। उसे बुखार है और वह संतरे की मांग कर रहा है। लेकिन उसकी माँ उसे कुछ नहीं दे सकती, उसके पास केवल नदी का पानी है, इसलिए वह रो रहा है। ओह, स्वैलो, स्वैलो, छोटा स्वैलो, क्या आप उसे मेरी तलवार के मूठ से रूबी नहीं लाएँगे? मैं इस आसन पर अटक गया हूँ और चल नहीं पा रहा हूँ।"

7.content:
"I am waited for in Egypt," said the Swallow. "My friends are flying up
and down the Nile, and talking to the large lotus-flowers. Soon they
will go to sleep in the tomb of the great King. The King is there
himself in his painted coffin. He is wrapped in yellow linen, and
embalmed with spices. Round his neck is a chain of pale green jade,
and his hands are like withered leaves."
"Swallow, Swallow, little Swallow," said the Prince, "will you not stay
with me for one night, and be my messenger? The boy is so thirsty, and
the mother so sad."
"I don't think I like boys," answered the Swallow. "Last summer, when I
was staying on the river, there were two rude boys, the miller's sons,
who were always throwing stones at me. They never hit me, of course;
we swallows fly far too well for that, and besides, I come of a family
famous for its agility; but still, it was a mark of disrespect."
But the Happy Prince looked so sad that the little Swallow was sorry.
"It is very cold here," he said; "but I will stay with you for one
night, and be your messenger."
"Thank you, little Swallow," said the Prince.

summary.current_page_summary_hindi: स्वालो को शुरू में हैप्पी प्रिंस के साथ रहने के बारे में यकीन नहीं है क्योंकि पहले उसके साथ अशिष्ट लड़कों के साथ अप्रिय मुठभेड़ हुई थी। हालाँकि, राजकुमार का दुखी चेहरा स्वालो को अपना मन बदलने के लिए मना लेता है। राजकुमार तब स्वालो से केवल एक रात के लिए अपने दूत के रूप में काम करने के लिए कहता है। ठंड महसूस करने के बावजूद, स्वालो इस अनुरोध पर सहमत हो जाता है।

novel_words.meaning: type of aquatic plant with showy flowers
novel_words.usage: The garden was filled with lotus-flowers, their beautiful blooms floating on the pond's surface.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'lotus-flowers' refers to the large, symbolic flowers that are often associated with ancient Egyptian culture and are mentioned in the story as a setting for the Swallow's friends to fly and talk.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: "जल कमल" शब्द एक प्रकार के जलीय पौधे को संदर्भित करता है जो अपने सुंदर फूलों के लिए जाना जाता है। ये पौधे अक्सर तालाबों और झीलों में पाए जाते हैं, और उनके बड़े, सपाट पत्ते होते हैं जो पानी की सतह पर तैरते हैं। जलकमल के फूल आम तौर पर सफेद या पीले रंग के होते हैं और प्याले के आकार के होते हैं। वे पानी की सतह से ऊपर उठने वाले लंबे तनों पर खिलते हैं। जल लिली बगीचों में लोकप्रिय हैं क्योंकि उनकी देखभाल करना आसान है और वे तालाब या झील में लालित्य का स्पर्श जोड़ सकते हैं।
novel_words.usage_hindi: उद्यान कमल के फूलों से भरा हुआ था, उनकी खूबसूरत पंखुड़ियां पानी की सतह पर तैर रही थीं।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस कहानी में, 'कमल के फूलों' का उपयोग बड़े, प्रतीकात्मक फूलों को दर्शाने के लिए किया जाता है जो आम तौर पर प्राचीन मिस्र की संस्कृति से जुड़े होते हैं। इन फूलों का उल्लेख एक ऐसी जगह के रूप में किया गया है जहाँ स्वालो के दोस्त उड़ सकते हैं और बातचीत कर सकते हैं।

novel_words.meaning: preserved or treated to prevent decay
novel_words.usage: The ancient Egyptian tomb was found to be embalmed, with the mummy of the pharaoh still intact.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'embalmed' refers to the process by which the King's body was preserved in order to prevent decay and ensure his immortality.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: बचाए रखा या इसे खराब होने से रोकने के लिए उपचारित किया गया
novel_words.usage_hindi: पुरातन मिस्र के मकबरे को संरक्षित पाया गया, जिसमें फ़ारोह का शरीर अभी भी अच्छी स्थिति में था।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, 'क्षतिग्रस्त' शब्द का उपयोग राजा के शरीर को सड़ने से बचाने के लिए उपयोग की जाने वाली विधि का वर्णन करने के लिए किया जाता है। यह प्रक्रिया यह सुनिश्चित करने के लिए की गई थी कि राजा का शरीर अक्षुण्ण रहे और समय के साथ सड़ न जाए।

novel_words.meaning: covered with paint or colored
novel_words.usage: The painting on the wall was beautiful, but it had been painted over many times since its original creation.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'painted' refers to the King's coffin, which is decorated with colorful images and symbols.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: पेंट या रंग से ढका हुआ
novel_words.usage_hindi: दीवार पर चित्रकला सुंदर थी, लेकिन इसे पहली बार बनाने के बाद से कई बार फिर से रंगा गया था।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, राजा के ताबूत का वर्णन करने के लिए 'चित्रकारी' शब्द का उपयोग किया जाता है। इस ताबूत को जीवंत चित्रों और प्रतीकों से सजाया गया है।

novel_words.meaning: dry and shriveled, often due to lack of water or nutrients
novel_words.usage: The once-beautiful flower had withered away, its petals dropping off.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'withered' refers to the King's hands, which are described as being like dry, shriveled leaves.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: सूखा और उखड़ना, अक्सर पर्याप्त पानी या पोषक तत्वों के न होने के कारण
novel_words.usage_hindi: वह फूल जो कभी बहुत सुंदर था, अपनी सुंदरता खो चुका था और उसकी पंखुड़ियां गिर गई थीं।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, राजा के हाथों का वर्णन करने के लिए 'सूखा' शब्द का उपयोग किया जाता है। उनकी तुलना सूखे, उखड़ते हुए पत्तों से की जाती है।

novel_words.meaning: disrespectful or impolite
novel_words.usage: The boy's behavior was rude, and he needed to learn some manners.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'rude' refers to the miller's sons' behavior towards the Swallow, which is described as being impolite and disrespectful.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: अभद्रता या असभ्यता
novel_words.usage_hindi: लड़के का व्यवहार असभ्य था और उसे कुछ शिष्टाचार के सबक की आवश्यकता थी।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, 'अशिष्ट' शब्द का उपयोग यह वर्णन करने के लिए किया जाता है कि मिल के बेटे स्वालो के साथ कैसा व्यवहार करते थे। यह व्यवहार विनम्र या सम्मानजनक नहीं था।

cultural_ref.significance: Egypt is a country in northeastern Africa with a rich history dating back to ancient civilizations such as the Egyptians, who are known for their pyramids, mummies, and pharaohs. The mention of Egypt may evoke images of the Nile River, which played a crucial role in the country's development.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, Egypt might be less familiar as a cultural or historical reference point compared to other parts of Africa or Asia.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: मिस्र अफ्रीका के पूर्वोत्तर भाग में स्थित एक देश है। इसका समृद्ध इतिहास प्राचीन मिस्रवासियों के समय से है। ये लोग अपने प्रभावशाली पिरामिड, अच्छी तरह से संरक्षित ममी और शक्तिशाली फारोह के लिए प्रसिद्ध हैं। जब लोग मिस्र के बारे में सोचते हैं, तो वे अक्सर नील नदी की कल्पना करते हैं। यह नदी देश के विकास और प्रगति के लिए महत्वपूर्ण थी।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत में हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, अफ्रीका या एशिया के अन्य हिस्सों की तुलना में मिस्र शायद एक सांस्कृतिक या ऐतिहासिक संदर्भ बिंदु के रूप में उतना प्रसिद्ध नहीं है।

cultural_ref.significance: The Nile River is one of the longest rivers in the world and has been a vital source of water and transportation for ancient civilizations, including the Egyptians. The mention of the Nile may evoke images of the river's annual flooding, which brought nutrient-rich silt to the surrounding land.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, the Nile River might be less familiar as a geographical reference point compared to other rivers in Asia or Africa.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: नील नदी एक बहुत लंबी नदी है जिसने मिस्र जैसे प्राचीन समाजों को पानी और परिवहन प्रदान करने में महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका निभाई है। जब आप नील नदी के बारे में सुनते हैं, तो आप शायद इसकी वार्षिक बाढ़ के बारे में सोच सकते हैं। यह बाढ़ आसपास के क्षेत्रों में समृद्ध मिट्टी लाती है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: जो लोग हिंदी बोलते हैं और भारत से हैं, उनके लिए नील नदी एशिया या अफ्रीका की अन्य नदियों की तुलना में अपनी भौगोलिक स्थिति के संदर्भ में उतनी प्रसिद्ध नहीं हो सकती है।

cultural_ref.significance: In Hinduism and Buddhism, the lotus flower is a sacred symbol of spiritual growth and enlightenment. In ancient Egypt, the lotus was also a revered flower, often depicted in art and literature as a symbol of beauty and purity.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, the mention of lotus-flowers might evoke images of Hindu or Buddhist symbolism, adding depth to their understanding of the story.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: हिंदू धर्म और बौद्ध धर्म दोनों में कमल का फूल एक अत्यंत सम्मानित प्रतीक है। यह आध्यात्मिक प्रगति और ज्ञान प्राप्त करने का प्रतिनिधित्व करता है। अतीत में, प्राचीन मिस्र में कमल की बहुत प्रशंसा की जाती थी। इसे अक्सर कला और कहानियों में सुंदरता और शुद्धता के प्रतीक के रूप में चित्रित किया जाता था।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत में हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए कमल के फूलों का उल्लेख हिंदू या बौद्ध मान्यताओं से संबंधित छवियों को जगा सकता है। इससे कहानी की उनकी समझ समृद्ध हो सकती है।

cultural_ref.significance: In ancient Egyptian culture, tombs were elaborate structures built for pharaohs and other high-ranking officials. The mention of a tomb in the story may evoke images of ancient Egyptian burial practices and the importance of preserving the dead.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, the concept of tombs might be less familiar as a cultural or historical reference point compared to Indian funeral practices.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: मिस्र के पुराने दिनों में, फ़िरौनों जैसे महत्वपूर्ण लोगों के लिए मकबरे नामक भव्य इमारतें बनाई जाती थीं। जब आप किसी कहानी में एक मकबरे के बारे में सुनते हैं, तो यह आपको याद दिला सकता है कि प्राचीन मिस्रवासी अपने मृतकों को कैसे दफनाना पसंद करते थे और वे अपने मृतकों को सुरक्षित रखने में कैसे विश्वास करते थे।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत में हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, मकबरों की अवधारणा उनकी संस्कृति या इतिहास में उतनी प्रसिद्ध या महत्वपूर्ण नहीं हो सकती है। ऐसा इसलिए है क्योंकि भारत में लोगों को दफ़नाने या शोक मनाने का तरीका पश्चिमी संस्कृतियों में आम तौर पर देखे जाने वाले तरीके से अलग है।

cultural_ref.significance: In ancient Egyptian culture, kings were believed to have divine authority and were often depicted in art and literature as powerful rulers. The mention of a king in the story may evoke images of pharaonic power and authority.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, the concept of monarchies might be less familiar as a cultural or historical reference point compared to Indian royal traditions.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: प्राचीन मिस्र के समाज में एक विशेष प्रकार की शक्ति थी जिसे देवताओं से प्राप्त माना जाता था। इस शक्ति को अक्सर कला और कहानियों में एक मजबूत नेता के रूप में चित्रित किया गया था। यदि किसी कहानी में किसी राजा का उल्लेख किया गया है, तो यह आपको प्राचीन मिस्र के शक्तिशाली शासकों की याद दिला सकता है, जिन्हें फारों के रूप में जाना जाता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत में हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, राजतंत्र का विचार शायद उतना प्रसिद्ध नहीं है या भारतीय शाही परंपराओं से उतना निकटता से संबंधित नहीं है।

cultural_ref.significance: In ancient Egyptian culture, jade was a highly valued stone used in jewelry and other decorative items. The mention of pale green jade might evoke images of ancient Egyptian craftsmanship and the importance of precious stones.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, jade might be less familiar as a cultural or historical reference point compared to Indian gemstones like rubies or emeralds.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: प्राचीन मिस्र के समाज में, लापिस लाजुली पत्थर का अत्यधिक सम्मान किया जाता था और अक्सर गहनों और अन्य सजावटी वस्तुओं में उपयोग किया जाता था। जब आप फीका पड़ते हुए हरे जेड के बारे में सुनते हैं, तो यह आपको प्राचीन मिस्रवासियों की कुशल शिल्प कौशल और कीमती पत्थरों के महत्व के बारे में सोचने पर मजबूर कर सकता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत में हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, ज़रकॉन शायद एक प्रसिद्ध सांस्कृतिक या ऐतिहासिक संदर्भ नहीं है। ऐसा इसलिए है क्योंकि वे पन्ना और पन्न जैसे अन्य कीमती पत्थरों से अधिक परिचित हैं, जिनका उपयोग आम तौर पर गहनों में किया जाता है।

cultural_ref.significance: In ancient Egyptian culture, princes were often depicted in art and literature as symbols of royal power and nobility. The mention of a prince in the story may evoke images of pharaonic succession and the importance of royal lineage.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, the concept of royalty might be less familiar as a cultural or historical reference point compared to Indian royal traditions.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: प्राचीन मिस्र के समाज में, राजकुमारों को अक्सर कला और लेखन में उनकी भागीदारी के माध्यम से राजा के अधिकार और उच्च सामाजिक स्थिति का प्रतिनिधित्व करते हुए चित्रित किया जाता था। जब किसी कहानी में एक राजकुमार का उल्लेख किया जाता है, तो यह फ़िरौन की विरासत और शाही परिवार की वंशावली के महत्व का संकेत दे सकता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत में हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, शाही परिवार की अवधारणा उनकी संस्कृति या इतिहास में उतनी प्रसिद्ध या प्रासंगिक नहीं हो सकती है। ऐसा इसलिए है क्योंकि उनकी सांस्कृतिक विरासत भारतीय शाही परंपराओं पर अधिक जोर देती है।

cultural_ref.significance: In Hindu mythology, the swallow is associated with the god Krishna and is often depicted in art and literature as a symbol of love and devotion. The mention of a swallow in the story may evoke images of Hindu mythology and symbolism.

cultural_ref.significance_hindi: हिंदू धार्मिक कहानियों में मोर को अक्सर भगवान कृष्ण से जोड़ा जाता है। इसे अक्सर कला और कहानियों में प्यार और भक्ति के प्रतीक के रूप में दर्शाया जाता है। जब एक कहानी में एक मोर का उल्लेख किया जाता है, तो यह लोगों को हिंदू धार्मिक कहानियों और उनके अंतर्निहित अर्थों की याद दिला सकता है।

So the Swallow picked out the great ruby from the Prince's sword,
and flew away with it in his beak over the roofs of the town.
He passed by the cathedral tower, where the white marble angels were
sculptured. He passed by the palace and heard the sound of dancing.
A beautiful girl came out on the balcony with her lover. "How wonderful
the stars are," he said to her, "and how wonderful is the power of
love!"
"I hope my dress will be ready in time for the State-ball," she
answered; "I have ordered passion-flowers to be embroidered on it;
but the seamstresses are so lazy."

novel_words.meaning_hindi: यहाँ कुछ फूल हैं जो अक्सर प्यार या जुनून से जुड़े होते हैंः गुलाबः ये शायद प्यार के सबसे प्रसिद्ध प्रतीक हैं। वे कई रंगों में आते हैं, प्रत्येक का अपना अर्थ है। उदाहरण के लिए, लाल गुलाबों का उपयोग अक्सर गहरे प्यार को व्यक्त करने के लिए किया जाता है, जबकि गुलाबी गुलाब प्रशंसा और आभार का प्रतीक हैं। ट्यूलिपः इन फूलों को अक्सर प्यार और जुनून के प्रतीक के रूप में देखा जाता है। वे वसंत और नवीनीकरण से भी जुड़े हुए हैं, जो एक रोमांटिक रिश्ते में एक नई शुरुआत का प्रतिनिधित्व कर सकते हैं। लिली: इन फूलों का उपयोग अक्सर शादी की व्यवस्थाओं में किया जाता है और वेलेंटाइन डे के गुलदस्ते के लिए एक लोकप्रिय विकल्प हैं। वे पवित्रता, मासूमियत और परिष्कृत सौंदर्य का प्रतीक हैं। ऑर्किडः ये फूल अक्सर विलासिता, सुंदरता और परिष्कार से जुड़े होते हैं। वे प्यार और जुनून के प्रतीक भी हैं, विशेष रूप से एशियाई संस्कृतियों में। सूरजमुखी: इन चमकीले और हंसमुख फूलों को अक्सर गर्मजोशी, खुशी और समर्पण के प्रतीक के रूप में देखा जाता है। वे एक मजबूत और स्थायी प्रेम का प्रतिनिधित्व कर सकते हैं। गुलाब: इन फूलों का उपयोग अक्सर शादी की व्यवस्थाओं में किया जाता है और वेलेंटाइन डे के गुलदस्ते के लिए एक लोकप्रिय विकल्प हैं। वे प्यार, आकर्षण और विशिष्टता का प्रतीक हैं। चमेलीः ये फूल अक्सर मासूमियत, पवित्रता और नई शुरुआत से जुड़े होते हैं। वे एक रोमांटिक रिश्ते में एक नई शुरुआत का प्रतिनिधित्व कर सकते हैं। पीनीः इन फूलों को अक्सर सौभाग्य, समृद्धि और एक खुशहाल विवाह के प्रतीक के रूप में देखा जाता है। वे रोमांस और जुनून से भी जुड़े हुए हैं। हिबिस्कसः ये फूल अक्सर उष्णकटिबंधीय सुंदरता और रोमांस से जुड़े होते हैं। वे एक भावुक और आकर्षक प्रेम का प्रतिनिधित्व कर सकते हैं। गेर्बेराः इन फूलों को अक्सर खुशी, मासूमियत और पवित्रता के प्रतीक के रूप में देखा जाता है। वे एक आनंदित और चंचल प्रेम का प्रतिनिधित्व कर सकते हैं। याद रखें, संस्कृति और संदर्भ के आधार पर फूलों का अर्थ अलग-अलग हो सकता है। ये केवल कुछ सामान्य संबंध और अर्थ हैं।

He passed over the river, and saw the lanterns hanging to the masts of
the ships. He passed over the Ghetto, and saw the old Jews bargaining
with each other, and weighing out money in copper scales. At last he
came to the poor house and looked in. The boy was tossing feverishly on
his bed, and the mother had fallen asleep, she was so tired. In he
hopped, and laid the great ruby on the table beside the woman's thimble.
Then he flew gently round the bed, fanning the boy's forehead with his
wings. "How cool I feel!" said the boy, "I must be getting better;"
and he sank into a delicious slumber.
Then the Swallow flew back to the Happy Prince, and told him what he had
done. "It is curious," he remarked, "but I feel quite warm now, although
it is so cold."
"That is because you have done a good action," said the Prince. And the
little Swallow began to think, and then he fell asleep. Thinking always
made him sleepy.

10.content:
When day broke he flew down to the river and had a bath. "What a
remarkable phenomenon," said the Professor of Ornithology as he was
passing over the bridge. "A swallow in winter!" And he wrote a long
letter about it to the local newspaper. Every one quoted it, it was full
of so many words that they could not understand.
"To-night I go to Egypt," said the Swallow, and he was in high spirits
at the prospect. He visited all the public monuments, and sat a long
time on top of the church steeple. Wherever he went the Sparrows
chirruped, and said to each other, "What a distinguished stranger!"
so he enjoyed himself very much.
When the moon rose he flew back to the Happy Prince. "Have you any
commissions for Egypt?" he cried; "I am just starting."
"Swallow, Swallow, little Swallow," said the Prince, "will you not stay
with me one night longer?"

10.grade5: One morning when it was time for day to start, he flew down to the river and took a bath. The Professor of Birds who was walking over the bridge said, 'Wow, look at that! A swallow in winter!' He wrote a long letter about it to the local newspaper. Everyone liked it, but they didn't understand all the words. 'Tonight I'm going to Egypt,' said the Swallow, and he was very happy because of this trip. He visited many famous buildings and sat on top of the church tower for a long time. Wherever he went, the Sparrows chirped and said to each other, 'Look at that cool bird!' So he had a great time. When the moon came up, he flew back to the Happy Prince. 'Do you have any jobs in Egypt?' he asked. 'I'm just starting my trip.' The Prince said, 'Swallow, please don't leave me yet. Can you stay with me one more night?'

11.content:
"I am waited for in Egypt," answered the Swallow. "To-morrow my friends
will fly up to the Second Cataract. The river-horse couches there among
the bulrushes, and on a great granite throne sits the God Memnon. All
night long he watches the stars, and when the morning star shines he
utters one cry of joy, and then he is silent. At noon the yellow lions
come down to the water's edge to drink. They have eyes like green
beryls, and their roar is louder than the roar of the cataract."
"Swallow, Swallow, little Swallow," said the Prince, "far away across
the city I see a young man in a garret. He is leaning over a desk
covered with papers, and in a tumbler by his side there is a bunch of
withered violets. His hair is brown and crisp, and his lips are red as a
pomegranate, and he has large and dreamy eyes. He is trying to finish a
play for the Director of the Theatre, but he is too cold to write any
more. There is no fire in the grate, and hunger has made him faint."
"I will wait with you one night longer," said the Swallow, who really
had a good heart. "Shall I take him another ruby?"

11.grade5: A swallow replied to the prince, 'I'll be in Egypt tomorrow.' The next day, my friends and I will fly over the Second Cataract. There, a river-horse rests among the bulrushes on a big granite throne. A god named Memnon sits there all night, watching the stars. When the morning star appears, he cries out with joy, then is quiet. At noon, yellow lions come to the water's edge to drink. They have green eyes and loud roars like the cataract.

12.content:
"Alas! I have no ruby now," said the Prince; "my eyes are all that I
have left. They are made of rare sapphires, which were brought out of
India a thousand years ago. Pluck out one of them and take it to him. He
will sell it to the jeweller, and buy food and firewood, and finish his
play."
"Dear Prince," said the Swallow, "I cannot do that"; and he began to
weep.
"Swallow, Swallow, little Swallow," said the Prince, "do as I command
you."
So the Swallow plucked out the Prince's eye, and flew away to the
student's garret. It was easy enough to get in, as there was a hole in
the roof. Through this he darted, and came into the room. The young man
had his head buried in his hands, so he did not hear the flutter of the
bird's wings, and when he looked up he found the beautiful sapphire
lying on the withered violets.
"I am beginning to be appreciated," he cried; "this is from some great
admirer. Now I can finish my play," and he looked quite happy.

47.content_hindi: "प्रिय राजकुमार," चिड़पंखी ने कहा, "मैं ऐसा नहीं कर सकती।" इसके बाद वह रोने लगी।

48.content:
"Swallow, Swallow, little Swallow," said the Prince, "do as I command
you."
48.content_hindi: "निगलो, निगलो, छोटा निगलो," राजकुमार ने कहा, "जो मैं तुम्हें करने के लिए कहता हूँ, वह करो।"

49.content:
So the Swallow plucked out the Prince's eye, and flew away to the
student's garret. It was easy enough to get in, as there was a hole in
the roof. Through this he darted, and came into the room. The young man
had his head buried in his hands, so he did not hear the flutter of the
bird's wings, and when he looked up he found the beautiful sapphire
lying on the withered violets.
49.content_hindi: चील ने राजकुमार की आंख निकाल दी और छात्र के अटारी में उड़ गई। भीतरी भाग में प्रवेश करना आसान था क्योंकि छत में एक छेद था। पक्षी ने इस छेद से तेजी से उड़ कर कमरे में प्रवेश कर लिया। युवक ने अपने सिर को अपने हाथों से ढक रखा था, इसलिए उसने पक्षी के पंखों के फड़फड़ाने की आवाज नहीं सुनी। जब उसने ऊपर देखा, तो उसने पीली पड़ी बैंगनी फूलों पर पड़ी सुंदर नीलम को देखा।

50.content:
"I am beginning to be appreciated," he cried; "this is from some great
admirer. Now I can finish my play," and he looked quite happy.
50.content_hindi: "मुझे पहचाना जाने लगा है," उन्होंने कहा; "यह एक बड़े प्रशंसक की तरफ से प्रशंसा है।" अब मैं अपना नाटक पूरा कर सकता हूँ," और वह बहुत खुश लग रहा था।

12.grade5: A prince said, 'I have no ruby left, but I still have my eyes. They are special sapphires that were brought from India a long time ago.' He asked the swallow to take one of his eyes to sell it for food and a place to live. The swallow refused and started crying. The prince told him to do what he said. So, the swallow took out the prince's eye and flew away to find some food. It was easy to get in because there was a hole in the roof. When the swallow entered the room, it saw the young man with his head on the table. He didn't hear the bird flying around him. When he looked up, he found one of the prince's special sapphires on the old flowers. The young man was happy because someone admired him and could finally finish his play.

13.content:
The next day the Swallow flew down to the harbour. He sat on the mast of
a large vessel and watched the sailors hauling big chests out of the
hold with ropes. "Heave a-hoy!" they shouted as each chest came up.
"I am going to Egypt!" cried the Swallow, but nobody minded, and when
the moon rose he flew back to the Happy Prince.
"I am come to bid you good-bye," he cried.
"Swallow, Swallow, little Swallow," said the Prince, "will you not stay
with me one night longer?"
"It is winter," answered the Swallow, "and the chill snow will soon be
here. In Egypt the sun is warm on the green palm-trees, and the
crocodiles lie in the mud and look lazily about them. My companions are
building a nest in the Temple of Baalbec, and the pink and white doves
are watching them, and cooing to each other. Dear Prince, I must leave
you, but I will never forget you, and next spring I will bring you back
two beautiful jewels in place of those you have given away. The ruby
shall be redder than a red rose, and the sapphire shall be as blue as
the great sea."

51.content:
The next day the Swallow flew down to the harbour. He sat on the mast of
a large vessel and watched the sailors hauling big chests out of the
hold with ropes. "Heave a-hoy!" they shouted as each chest came up.
"I am going to Egypt!" cried the Swallow, but nobody minded, and when
the moon rose he flew back to the Happy Prince.
51.content_hindi: अगले दिन, स्वालो पक्षी बंदरगाह पर उतरा। यह एक बड़े जहाज के मस्तूल पर बैठा और नाविकों को रस्सी का उपयोग करके जहाज के पोत से बड़ी-बड़ी अलमारी बाहर निकालते हुए देखा। नाविक "हैव ए-हॉय!" चिल्लाते थे। हर बार जब एक छाती बाहर निकाली जाती थी। तब स्वालो ने घोषणा की, "मैं मिस्र जा रहा हूँ!" लेकिन, किसी ने इस पर ध्यान नहीं दिया। जब चंद्रमा निकला, तो स्वालो हैप्पी प्रिंस के पास लौट आया।

52.content: "I am come to bid you good-bye," he cried.
52.content_hindi: उन्होंने कहा, "मैं आपसे अलविदा कहने आया हूँ।"

53.content:
"Swallow, Swallow, little Swallow," said the Prince, "will you not stay
with me one night longer?"
53.content_hindi: "निगल लो, निगल लो, छोटी निगल," राजकुमार ने पूछा, "क्या तुम एक और रात मेरे साथ नहीं रुकोगी?"

54.content:
"It is winter," answered the Swallow, "and the chill snow will soon be
here. In Egypt the sun is warm on the green palm-trees, and the
crocodiles lie in the mud and look lazily about them. My companions are
building a nest in the Temple of Baalbec, and the pink and white doves
are watching them, and cooing to each other. Dear Prince, I must leave
you, but I will never forget you, and next spring I will bring you back
two beautiful jewels in place of those you have given away. The ruby
shall be redder than a red rose, and the sapphire shall be as blue as
the great sea."
54.content_hindi: "सर्दियों का मौसम है," चिड़पहिया पक्षी ने जवाब दिया, "और जल्द ही ठंडी बर्फ यहाँ आ जाएगी।" मिस्र में, सूरज हरे ताड़ के पेड़ों पर गर्मजोशी से चमकता है, और मगरमच्छ आस-पास देखते हुए गीली मिट्टी में सुस्त होकर लेट जाते हैं। मेरे दोस्त बाल्बेक के मंदिर में एक घोंसला बना रहे हैं, और गुलाबी और सफेद कबूतर उन्हें देख रहे हैं, एक दूसरे से धीरे से कूक कर रहे हैं। प्रिय राजकुमार, मुझे अब जाना है, लेकिन मैं आपको नहीं भूलूंगा। अगले वसंत में, मैं आपको दो प्यारे गहने वापस लाऊंगा जो आपने दिए हैं। मनमोहक पत्थर लाल गुलाब के समान लाल होगा, और नीलम का रंग विशाल समुद्र के समान नीला होगा।"

13.grade5: The next day, the Swallow flew to the harbour. He sat on the mast of a big boat and watched the sailors pulling out big chests with ropes. 'Heave a-hoy!' they shouted as each chest came up. 'I'm going to Egypt!' said the Swallow, but nobody paid attention. When the moon rose, he flew back to the Happy Prince. 'I've come to say goodbye,' he said. The Prince looked at him and said, 'Swallow, won't you stay with me one more night?' 'It's winter,' replied the Swallow, 'and soon it will be cold outside. In Egypt, the sun is warm on the palm trees, and the crocodiles are sleeping in the mud. My friends are building a nest in the Temple of Baalbec, and the pink and white doves are watching them, cooing to each other. Dear Prince, I have to leave you, but I'll never forget you. Next spring, I'll bring you back two beautiful jewels as a gift. The ruby will be redder than a red rose, and the sapphire will be as blue as the sea.

14.content:
"In the square below," said the Happy Prince, "there stands a little
match-girl. She has let her matches fall in the gutter, and they are all
spoiled. Her father will beat her if she does not bring home some money,
and she is crying. She has no shoes or stockings, and her little head is
bare. Pluck out my other eye and give it to her, and her father will not
beat her."
"I will stay with you one night longer," said the Swallow, "but I cannot
pluck out your eye. You would be quite blind then."
"Swallow, Swallow, little Swallow," said the Prince, "do as I command
you."
So he plucked out the Prince's other eye, and darted down with it. He
swooped past the match-girl, and slipped the jewel into the palm of her
hand. "What a lovely bit of glass!" cried the little girl; and she ran
home, laughing.
Then the Swallow came back to the Prince. "You are blind now," he said,
"so I will stay with you always."
"No, little Swallow," said the poor Prince, "you must go away to Egypt."
"I will stay with you always," said the Swallow, and he slept at the
Prince's feet.

14.grade5: There was a square where a happy prince lived. A little girl was standing there. She had dropped her matches in the gutter and they were all ruined. Her father would get angry if she didn't bring home some money, so she was crying. She didn't have any shoes or stockings, and her head was bare. The prince said to her, 'Please take out my other eye and give it to you. If you do, your father won't be mean to you.' A swallow heard the prince's words and flew down. He took out the prince's other eye and gave it to the girl. She was so happy! She ran home laughing. The swallow came back to the prince. 'You can't see now,' he said. So, he decided to stay with the prince forever.'

15.content:
All the next day he sat on the Prince's shoulder, and told him stories
of what he had seen in strange lands. He told him of the red ibises,
who stand in long rows on the banks of the Nile, and catch gold-fish in
their beaks; of the Sphinx, who is as old as the world itself, and lives
in the desert, and knows everything; of the merchants, who walk slowly
by the side of their camels and carry amber beads in their hands; of the
King of the Mountains of the Moon, who is as black as ebony, and
worships a large crystal; of the great green snake that sleeps in a palm
tree, and has twenty priests to feed it with honey-cakes; and of the
pygmies who sail over a big lake on large flat leaves, and are always at
war with the butterflies.
"Dear little Swallow," said the Prince, "you tell me of marvellous
things, but more marvellous than anything is the suffering of men and of
women. There is no Mystery so great as Misery. Fly over my city, little
Swallow, and tell me what you see there."

62.content_hindi: अगले दिन, कहानीकार राजकुमार के कंधे पर बैठकर दूर-दूर की जगहों पर अपने रोमांच की कहानियाँ सुनाता है। उन्होंने लाल इबिस के बारे में बात की, जो नील नदी के किनारे लंबी पंक्तियों में पाए जाते हैं और वे अपने चोंच से कैसे सुनहरी मछली पकड़ते हैं। उन्होंने स्फिंक्स के बारे में भी बात की, जो एक प्राचीन प्राणी है जो रेगिस्तान में रहता है और जिसके पास सारा ज्ञान है। उन्होंने उन व्यापारियों का उल्लेख किया, जो अपने हाथों में अंबर मोतियों को ले कर अपने ऊंटों के साथ धीरे-धीरे आगे बढ़ते हैं। उन्होंने चंद्रमा के पहाड़ों के राजा के बारे में भी बात की, जो अबरुन के समान काला है और एक बड़े क्रिस्टल की पूजा करता है। उन्होंने एक बड़े हरे सांप के बारे में भी बताया जो एक ताड़ के पेड़ पर सोया रहता है, और बीस पुजारी होते हैं जो उसे शहद के केक खिलाते हैं। अंत में, उन्होंने उन पिग्मी लोगों के बारे में बात की जो बड़ी सपाट पत्तियों पर एक बड़ी झील के पार यात्रा करते हैं और हमेशा तितलियों के साथ लड़ाई में लगे रहते हैं।

He also told him about the Sphinx, which is as old as the world and lives in the desert. The Sphinx knows everything! He shared stories of merchants who walk slowly by their camels, carrying pretty beads in their hands. 16.content:
So the Swallow flew over the great city, and saw the rich making merry
in their beautiful houses, while the beggars were sitting at the gates.
He flew into dark lanes, and saw the white faces of starving children
looking out listlessly at the black streets. Under the archway of a
bridge two little boys were lying in one another's arms to try and keep
themselves warm. "How hungry we are!" they said. "You must not lie
here," shouted the Watchman, and they wandered out into the rain.
Then he flew back and told the Prince what he had seen.
"I am covered with fine gold," said the Prince, "you must take it off,
leaf by leaf, and give it to my poor; the living always think that gold
can make them happy."
Leaf after leaf of the fine gold the Swallow picked off, till the Happy
Prince looked quite dull and grey. Leaf after leaf of the fine gold he
brought to the poor, and the children's faces grew rosier, and they
laughed and played games in the street. "We have bread now!" they cried.

16.grade5: A swallow flew over a big city. It saw people who were rich and happy in their nice houses. But it also saw people who didn't have much food, sitting at the gates. The swallow went into dark streets and saw kids with white faces looking sad at the black pavement. Under a bridge, two little boys were hugging each other to stay warm. 'We're very hungry!' they said. A watchman told them to move away because it was raining. Then the swallow came back and told the prince what it had seen. The prince said, 'I have gold that's covered in gold leaves. I want you to take off some of these leaves and give them to my poor people.' So the swallow took off leaf after leaf of the gold. At first, the prince looked a little sad. But when he gave the gold to the poor kids, their faces got happier and they started playing in the street. 'We have bread now!' they cheered.

17.content:
Then the snow came, and after the snow came the frost. The streets
looked as if they were made of silver, they were so bright and
glistening; long icicles like crystal daggers hung down from the eaves
of the houses, everybody went about in furs, and the little boys wore
scarlet caps and skated on the ice.
The poor little Swallow grew colder and colder, but he would not leave
the Prince, he loved him too well. He picked up crumbs outside the
baker's door when the baker was not looking, and tried to keep himself
warm by flapping his wings.
But at last he knew that he was going to die. He had just strength to
fly up to the Prince's shoulder once more. "Good-bye, dear Prince!"
he murmured, "will you let me kiss your hand?"
"I am glad that you are going to Egypt at last, little Swallow," said
the Prince, "you have stayed too long here; but you must kiss me on the
lips, for I love you."
"It is not to Egypt that I am going," said the Swallow. "I am going to
the House of Death. Death is the brother of Sleep, is he not?"
And he kissed the Happy Prince on the lips, and fell down dead at his
feet.

17.grade5: One day, it started to snow and then frost came. The streets looked like they were made of silver because everything was so bright and shiny. Long icicles hung from the houses' roofs like sharp crystals. People wore warm clothes and little boys wore red hats and skated on the ice. A small swallow bird got colder and colder, but he didn't want to leave the prince's side. He liked the prince too much. The swallow found food outside a bakery when no one was looking and tried to stay warm by flapping his wings. Eventually, the swallow knew it was going to die. He had just enough strength to fly up to the prince's shoulder again. 'Goodbye, dear prince!' he whispered. 'Will you let me kiss your hand?' The prince said, 'I'm glad you're going to Egypt because you've been here too long. But I want you to kiss me on the lips because I love you.' The swallow said, 'I'm not going to Egypt. I'm going to a place called Death. Is that right?' He kissed the happy prince on the lips and fell down dead at his feet.

At that moment a curious crack sounded inside the statue, as if
something had broken. The fact is that the leaden heart had snapped
right in two. It certainly was a dreadfully hard frost.
Early the next morning the Mayor was walking in the square below in
company with the Town Councillors. As they passed the column he looked
up at the statue: "Dear me! how shabby the Happy Prince looks!" he said.
"How shabby, indeed!" cried the Town Councillors, who always agreed with
the Mayor; and they went up to look at it.
"The ruby has fallen out of his sword, his eyes are gone, and he is
golden no longer," said the Mayor; "in fact, he is little better than a
beggar!"
"Little better than a beggar," said the Town Councillors.
"And here is actually a dead bird at his feet!" continued the Mayor. "We
must really issue a proclamation that birds are not to be allowed to die
here." And the Town Clerk made a note of the suggestion.
So they pulled down the statue of the Happy Prince. "As he is no longer
beautiful he is no longer useful," said the Art Professor at the
University.

78.content: "Little better than a beggar," said the Town Councillors.
78.content_hindi: नगर परिषद के सदस्यों ने उन्हें "एक भिखारी से थोड़ा बेहतर" बताया।

79.content:
"And here is actually a dead bird at his feet!" continued the Mayor. "We
must really issue a proclamation that birds are not to be allowed to die
here." And the Town Clerk made a note of the suggestion.
79.content_hindi: मेयर ने कहा, "देखिए, उसके ठीक सामने एक मरा हुआ पक्षी है!" हमें आधिकारिक घोषणा करने की आवश्यकता है कि पक्षियों को यहाँ मरने की अनुमति नहीं दी जानी चाहिए।" टाउन क्लर्क ने इस विचार को लिख लिया।

80.content:
So they pulled down the statue of the Happy Prince. "As he is no longer
beautiful he is no longer useful," said the Art Professor at the
University.
80.content_hindi: उन्होंने हैप्पी प्रिंस की मूर्ति हटा दी। विश्वविद्यालय के कला प्रोफेसर ने कहा, "चूंकि वह अब सुंदर नहीं है, वह अब उपयोगी नहीं है।"

18.grade5: One day, a strange crack sounded inside the statue. It was as if something had broken. The leaden heart of the Happy Prince had snapped in two. The air was very cold that morning. The Mayor was walking in the square with some important people. As they passed by the column, he looked up at the statue and said, 'Oh my! The Happy Prince looks very sad!' He meant that the prince's crown was missing, his eyes were gone, and he wasn't shiny anymore. In fact, he looked like a poor person!

19.content:
Then they melted the statue in a furnace, and the Mayor held a meeting
of the Corporation to decide what was to be done with the metal. "We
must have another statue, of course," he said, "and it shall be a statue
of myself."
"Of myself," said each of the Town Councillors, and they quarrelled.
When I last heard of them they were quarrelling still.
"What a strange thing!" said the overseer of the workmen at the foundry.
"This broken lead heart will not melt in the furnace. We must throw it
away." So they threw it on a dust-heap where the dead Swallow was also
lying.
"Bring me the two most precious things in the city," said God to one of
His Angels; and the Angel brought Him the leaden heart and the dead
bird.
"You have rightly chosen," said God, "for in my garden of Paradise this
little bird shall sing for evermore, and in my city of gold the Happy
Prince shall praise me."

summary.page_summary_so_far_hindi: राजकुमार और स्वालो के बीच बातचीत एक ऐसे युवक के बारे में है जो एक छोटे से कमरे में रहता है जिसे गारेट के नाम से जाना जाता है। यह युवक एक नाटक लिखने की कोशिश कर रहा है। बातचीत उनके संघर्षों और राजकुमार की उन्हें सलाह के बारे में है। बातचीत की शुरुआत राजकुमार द्वारा स्वालो से पूछने से होती है कि क्या वह एक ऐसे युवक को जानता है जो एक अटारी में रहता है। स्वालो जवाब देता है कि वह ऐसे व्यक्ति को जानता है। राजकुमार तब स्वालो से इस युवक के बारे में और बताने के लिए कहता है। द स्वॉलो बताते हैं कि लड़का बहुत प्रतिभाशाली है और उसके पास बहुत सारी क्षमता है। हालाँकि, वह एक नाटक लिखने के लिए संघर्ष कर रहा है क्योंकि वह निश्चित नहीं है कि किस विषय पर लिखना है। राजकुमार तब उस युवक को कुछ सलाह देता है। वह उसे बताता है कि उसे ऐसी चीज़ के बारे में लिखना चाहिए जिसके बारे में वह भावुक है। राजकुमार सुझाव देते हैं कि युवक को अपने जीवन और अनुभवों के बारे में लिखना चाहिए। वह युवक से कहता है कि दूसरों को उसके काम के बारे में क्या लगता है, इस बारे में उसे बहुत ज्यादा चिंता नहीं करनी चाहिए। राजकुमार उस युवक को सलाह देता है कि वह अपनी खुद की रचनात्मक दृष्टि पर ध्यान केंद्रित करे और इस बात की चिंता न करे कि दूसरे उसके काम के बारे में क्या सोचेंगे। बातचीत का अंत राजकुमार द्वारा उस युवक को लिखने के लिए और अपने सपनों को न छोड़ने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करने के साथ होता है। राजकुमार को लगता है कि युवक में बहुत क्षमता है और वह अंततः अपने लेखन के पेशे में सफल होगा।
summary.current_page_summary_hindi: मेयर का मानना है कि उनकी एक प्रतिमा आवश्यक है। हालाँकि, नगर पार्षद इस बारे में असहमत हैं। एक पर्यवेक्षक टूटे हुए सीसे के हृदय से छुटकारा पाने का प्रस्ताव रखता है। बाद में, परमेश्वर इस टूटे हुए हृदय का उपयोग स्वर्ग में एक उद्यान बनाने के लिए करता है। इस बगीचे में, एक मृत पक्षी हमेशा के लिए गाएगा, और हैप्पी प्रिंस भगवान की प्रशंसा करेगा।

cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत से हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, स्वर्ग के उद्यान के विचार को समझने से उन्हें कहानी की आध्यात्मिकता और उच्च शक्ति से पुरस्कार के विषयों को समझने में मदद मिल सकती है।

cultural_ref.part_of_text_hindi: सोने का शहर
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: यह शब्द सोने से बने एक पौराणिक या प्रतीकात्मक शहर को संदर्भित करता है, जिसे अक्सर धन और सौभाग्य से जोड़ा जाता है। यहाँ, यह एक स्वर्गीय स्थान या स्वर्ग की ओर इशारा कर रहा हो सकता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत से हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, सोने से बने शहर के विचार को समझने से उन्हें भौतिक संपत्ति और आध्यात्मिक पुरस्कार के बारे में कहानी के विषयों को समझने में मदद मिल सकती है।

cultural_ref.significance: A reference to a character in Oscar Wilde's poem 'The Happy Prince and the Golden Bird'. The Happy Prince is a symbol of joy, kindness, and selflessness. In this context, it is likely referring to a symbolic representation of a virtuous individual.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, understanding the reference to the Happy Prince can provide insight into the story's themes of morality and character development.
cultural_ref.part_of_text_hindi: हैप्पी प्रिंस
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: द हैप्पी प्रिंस ऑस्कर वाइल्ड की एक कविता 'द हैप्पी प्रिंस एंड द गोल्डन बर्ड' का एक पात्र है। इस चरित्र को अक्सर खुशी, दया और बदले में कुछ भी उम्मीद किए बिना देने के प्रतीक के रूप में देखा जाता है। यहाँ, इसका उपयोग किसी ऐसे व्यक्ति को दर्शाने के लिए किया जा सकता है जो अपने अच्छे कर्मों और दयालु स्वभाव के लिए जाना जाता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत से हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, हैप्पी प्रिंस को समझने से उन्हें कहानी के सही और गलत के विषयों को समझने में मदद मिल सकती है और कैसे पात्र समय के साथ बदलते हैं।

cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, understanding the reference to the Swallow can provide insight into the story's themes of mortality and the afterlife.
cultural_ref.part_of_text_hindi: निगलना
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: यह शब्द एक प्रकार के पक्षी को संदर्भित करता है जिसे आम तौर पर विभिन्न समाजों में शोक या मृत्यु से जोड़ा जाता है। यहाँ, इसका उपयोग संभवतः मृत्यु के विचार का प्रतीक के रूप में किया जा रहा है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत से हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, स्वालो के उल्लेख को समझने से उन्हें मृत्यु और हमारे मरने के बाद क्या होता है, इस बारे में कहानी के विचारों को समझने में मदद मिल सकती है।

cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking people from India, understanding the reference to the leaden heart can provide insight into the story's themes of love and sacrifice.
cultural_ref.part_of_text_hindi: भरा हुआ हृदय
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: यह वाक्यांश एक ऐसे प्रतीक के बारे में है जो प्यार या भक्ति का प्रतिनिधित्व करता है। यह शायद एक हृदय प्रतीक के बारे में बात कर रहा है, जो प्यार या स्नेह का एक सामान्य प्रतिनिधित्व है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत से हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, सीसे के समान हृदय के उल्लेख को समझने से उन्हें कहानी के प्रेम और निस्वार्थ दान के विषयों को समझने में मदद मिल सकती है।

19.grade5: Then they melted the statue in a big fire. The Mayor had a meeting with the town leaders to decide what to do with the metal. 'We need another statue,' he said, 'and it should be a statue of me.' 'Of me' said each of the town leaders, and they started arguing. When I last heard about them, they were still fighting. A worker at the factory said, 'This broken lead heart won't melt in the fire. We need to throw it away.' So they threw it on a pile of trash where a dead bird was also lying. God told one of His angels to bring Him two special things from the city. The angel brought Him the leaden heart and the dead bird. 'You chose correctly,' said God, 'because in my beautiful garden, this little bird will sing forever, and in my golden city, the Happy Prince will praise me.'
